name: Amazon EC2 Pricing Models
description: Flashcards explaining different EC2 pricing options and their ideal use cases for cost optimization and flexibility.

cards.front: You’re launching a test server for 2 days to validate an application’s performance. Which EC2 pricing option is most suitable?
cards.back: **On-Demand Instances** are ideal for short-term or unpredictable workloads with no upfront payment and pay-per-use pricing.
cards.example: A QA team runs a test suite on an EC2 instance for 48 hours, paying only for the compute time used.
cards.subject: Amazon EC2 Pricing

glossary.definition: EC2 instances billed by the second or hour with no long-term commitment, suitable for short-term or unpredictable workloads.

cards.front: Your company wants to reduce EC2 costs over the next 3 years by committing to consistent compute usage. What pricing model fits best?
cards.back: **EC2 Savings Plans** provide up to 72% savings by committing to a specific usage amount for 1 or 3 years, applied across EC2 regardless of instance family or Region.
cards.example: A company commits to $20/hour for compute over 3 years and receives discounts on matching EC2 usage.
cards.subject: Amazon EC2 Pricing

glossary.definition: Flexible pricing models offering discounted rates for a committed hourly compute usage across EC2 services.

cards.front: You’re planning to run a high-availability application for 3 years. What EC2 pricing model can offer cost savings with commitment?
cards.back: **Reserved Instances** offer significant discounts (especially 3-year terms) and are best for steady-state or predictable workloads.
cards.example: A retail company runs its ecommerce platform on Reserved Instances to reduce compute costs long-term.
cards.subject: Amazon EC2 Pricing

glossary.definition: Discounted EC2 pricing in exchange for a 1- or 3-year usage commitment for specific instance attributes.

cards.front: You’re running data processing jobs that can tolerate interruptions and want the lowest cost. Which EC2 option fits best?
cards.back: **Spot Instances** use unused capacity and offer up to 90% savings but can be interrupted if AWS needs the capacity.
cards.example: A team uses Spot Instances to analyze marketing data in batches overnight when capacity is cheaper.
cards.mnemonic: Spot = Save a Lot (But Can Stop)
cards.subject: Amazon EC2 Pricing

glossary.definition: EC2 instances using spare capacity at discounted prices, suitable for interruptible or flexible jobs.

cards.front: A company must use its own software licenses and needs full control over the physical server. Which EC2 pricing option supports this?
cards.back: **Dedicated Hosts** provide a physical EC2 server fully allocated to one customer, allowing license compliance and hardware control.
cards.example: An enterprise runs Oracle software on a Dedicated Host to comply with per-core licensing agreements.
cards.subject: Amazon EC2 Pricing

glossary.definition: A physical EC2 server dedicated to one customer, useful for licensing and compliance needs.
